info.title: Review of Symptoms
info.description: Your doctor might ask you a lot of questions after it seems like the questioning is almost done. They will go through questions, asking about what seems like anything and everything from head to toe. You might start getting annoyed because it seems like you are responding “no” to almost every question. Didn’t the doctor ask you enough about what you came in with to figure it out? Why is the doctor trying to fish for more seemingly useless information and wasting your time?

questions.question: Any fatigue or difficulty sleeping?
questions.answer: Tiredness can play a role in many different diseases. Fatigue can be from things such as anemia or infections.

questions.question: Any constant, chronic pain?
questions.answer: Doctors want to address any pain you are having so that they can help you feel better.

questions.question: Any general feelings of feeling unwell?
questions.answer: Doctors want to address any feelings of being unwell so they can help you feel better.

questions.question: Any fevers?
questions.answer: This can mean that you have a possible infection that the doctor will want to investigate further.

questions.question: Any chronic (long term) pain in your head or neck?
questions.answer: Doctors want to know this so they know to focus on an area during the physical exam.

questions.question: Any acute (short term) pain in your head or neck?
questions.answer: This can indicate something simple like a muscle cramp, or something more serious, like infection and inflammation

questions.question: Any noticeable masses?
questions.answer: Doctors like to make sure they don’t miss anything important, like new masses showing up

questions.question: Any changes in hearing?
questions.answer: Hearing changes can be because of damage to the little hairs deep inside your ears that help conduct sound, wax, an issue with a neural pathway, infection, and much more! Some causes are normal, like with aging, and some can be worrisome

questions.question: Any pain in your ear or discharge (liquid/pus coming out of the ear)?
questions.answer: This question relates to any injury or infection in the ear

questions.question: Any nasal dripping, stuffiness, or post nasal drip?
questions.answer: Post nasal drip, or mucus dripping down to your throat while you sleep, is actually one of the most common causes for long term cough! These pesky changes can point to an infection or just allergies.

questions.question: Any changes in your voice?
questions.answer: While there can be simple causes to changes in voice (like yelling at a concert), damage to or compression of certain nerves can cause changes to your voice

questions.question: Any toothaches or sensitivity in your mouth?
questions.answer: Infection or dental issues can cause these problems.

questions.question: Any sores or open wounds near or in your mouth?
questions.answer: These can be a sign of infection.

questions.question: Any sudden changes in levels of consciousness?
questions.answer: This is an especially important and concerning finding. Even though you might be fine while at the doctor’s office, if you had a change in your level of consciousness (ex: you had recent fainting spells), this is something your doctor would want to find out the cause for.

questions.question: Any recent seizures?
questions.answer: This can be a sign of overactivity in the brain. One seizure is not very concerning, but is important to monitor/keep track of. If they are happening repeatedly, the doctor can help you find ways to control them

questions.question: Any numbness?
questions.answer: Numbness can indicate nerve problems.

questions.question: Any weakness?
questions.answer: Sudden change in muscle tone, especially on one side, can imply a few causes, and it is important to know about weakness to rule out the more serious causes

questions.question: Any dizziness/balance issues?
questions.answer: This might seem weird, but balance problems can actually be because of problems with your ear! The fluid in your ear helps you know what direction you are turning in and can help your body adjust to head movement. If the levels are off, you might start feeling dizzy. Problems with certain nerve pathways can also cause dizziness, so this is one of the things doctors like to rule out!

questions.question: Any headaches?
questions.answer: There are a lot of causes for headaches and a lot of different types! This is another one where doctors like to rule out the most serious causes if you have this symptom.

questions.question: Any change in vision?
questions.answer: You might need a new eye glasses prescription or there might be a problem in one of the pathways your visual system uses to help you see and understand what you are seeing

questions.question: Any blurriness or double vision?
questions.answer: These can point to either a problem with your eyes, muscles around your eyes, or in the brain. Doctors will want to look more into this during your physical exam and may recommend imaging or other tests.

questions.question: Any pain in your eyes?
questions.answer: Pain can point to a variety of things including an object getting in your eye, headaches, and infection.

questions.question: Any redness in your eyes?
questions.answer: Redness can be because of allergies, infection, or tiny vessels in your eyes bleeding (although much less likely)

questions.question: Any itchiness or discharge from your eyes?
questions.answer: This is usually because of allergies, but the doctor will probably want to make sure you don’t have conjunctivitis, more commonly known as Pink Eye! (This is an infection that can spread to other people and needs to be treated with certain drops)

questions.question: Any difficulties reading?
questions.answer: Vision changes over time. Typically, as we age our reading vision declines, and your doctor may recommend getting reading glasses.

questions.question: Any chest pain?
questions.answer: Chest pain is tricky. The major thing the doctor wants to rule out, and what you might be concerned about, is a heart attack. But there are different types of chest pain (burning, pressure, etc), and many different causes. It can be because of something simple like heartburn. Figuring out the cause is important.

questions.question: Any palpitations [heart racing]?
questions.answer: Palpitations can have many causes such as anxiety or mitral valve prolapse. Your doctor will want to pay attention to your heart during your physical exam or order a Holter monitor (a take-home EKG machine) to learn more about your palpitations.

questions.question: Any swelling in your lower legs?
questions.answer: This is called peripheral edema and can point to different vascular processes including congestive heart failure (CHF).

questions.question: Any leg pain while walking around?
questions.answer: Leg pain while walking is called claudication (cramps!) and your doctor will want to look further into this. This can point to atherosclerosis (plaque build up in your arteries) and your doctor will want to give you medicines to prevent it from progressing any further.

questions.question: Any difficulty breathing lying down?
questions.answer: Breathing while lying down can help a doctor narrow the differential down to different heart conditions. Typically congestive heart failure causes problems with breathing at night.

questions.question: How many pillows do you sleep with at night?
questions.answer: Doctors ask this because it relates to congestive heart failure. The more pillows you use, the more your doctor will want to get you started on treatment.

questions.question: Have you been waking up at night because you can’t breathe?
questions.answer: This can happen if fluid is backing up from your heart to your lungs and is especially common in certain illnesses when you are lying flat on your back. It can also be because of sleep apnea, causing a person to snore.

questions.question: Any difficulty breathing on exertion [with excess movement, like climbing stairs]?
questions.answer: Difficulty breathing when moving can point to many different things. Your doctor will want to listen to your chest to hear the sounds when you breathe (check out the physical exam to learn more about breath sounds). The different sounds or lack of sounds can point a doctor to a particular disease.

questions.question: Any changes in your normal exercise ability?
questions.answer: A change in your normal exercise can be a sign of your lungs not working how they are supposed. Your doctor will want to investigate this further with the physical exam and possibly pulmonary function tests (PFTs).

questions.question: Any coughing?
questions.answer: Coughing can point to many different things going on with your lungs. It can be a sign of infection, lung disease and cancer(much rarer than the rest).

questions.question: Does anything come up or is it a dry cough?
questions.answer: Dry cough vs mucus coming out of your cough can point to different processes. Dry coughs can point to things such as asthma and post nasal drip, while a wet cough can be a sign of bronchitis or infection.

questions.question: What color is it?
questions.answer: It may sound gross, but the color and consistency can point to different germs in your lungs.

questions.question: How much is it?
questions.answer: Different diseases cause varying amounts of mucus to build up, which can help doctors on their differential diagnosis.

questions.question: When does it start/stop?
questions.answer: The length of time of a cough can lead a doctor to different diagnoses depending if it has only been a few days vs a few months.

questions.question: Any difficulty breathing at rest?
questions.answer: This can point to something that could be more severe and your doctor will want to investigate.

questions.question: Is it difficult to get air in, out, or both?
questions.answer: Some diseases make it harder to get air in (pulmonary fibrosis) while other diseases make it harder to blow air out of your lungs (COPD).

questions.question: Any wheezing?
questions.answer: Wheezing can point to different lung diseases. Asthma commonly causes wheezing as well as some infections

questions.question: Any snoring?
questions.answer: Snoring can point to something like sleep apnea or an obstructed airway. Sleep apnea can make you feel tired even though you are getting enough sleep. Depending on how much snoring and other factors you have, your doctor may order additional tests to check for sleep apnea.

questions.question: Any feelings of heartburn?
questions.answer: People can experience varying sensations with heartburn, ranging from migrating pain in the chest to a sharp sensation to a burning sensation. Heartburn famously is associated with acid reflux. These different sensations can help doctors on their differential diagnosis.

questions.question: Any pain in your abdomen?
questions.answer: The abdomen is divided into four squares during the physical exam. Each square contains different organs. Sensitivity or pain  in specific squares can point to different diagnoses. Your doctor will focus on this area during the physical exam.

questions.question: Any pain with or after swallowing?
questions.answer: Difficulty swallowing can be because of a problem with the nerves in your neck, your throat muscles, or your esophagus. Your doctor will check this further in the physical exam.

questions.question: Any nausea?
questions.answer: Nausea can have many causes and your doctor will use what was learned during the interview and the physical exam to help address any nausea.

questions.question: Any Vomiting?
questions.answer: It may sound gross, but your vomit can be very informative.

questions.question: How would you describe the consistency?
questions.answer: The consistency can help a doctor know if it is caused by food poisoning, infection or another other G.I. problem,

questions.question: Was there any blood?
questions.answer: Throwing up blood can be rather scary, and letting your doctor know it occurred is important because there could be a bleed somewhere along your G.I. tract, infection or other G.I. diseases.

questions.question: How much?
questions.answer: The amount of vomit can point to different diseases.

questions.question: How many times and for how long?
questions.answer: Doctors want to know this so they can know if this a new issue or something that has been going on for a while because it can change their diagnosis.

questions.question: Any abdominal swelling?
questions.answer: Abdominal swelling can be caused by variety of causes from inflammation to malnutrition (not getting enough nutrients) that your doctor may order tests for.

questions.question: Have you passed any gas?
questions.answer: It may be a little gross to talk about farting, but frequency and odor of farts can give your doctor a lot of information about your intestines, constipation, diet, medication side effects and infections.

questions.question: Any loose stools [diarrhea]?
questions.answer: Diarrhea is a little gross, but it is a useful symptom for doctors to know of because it can help diagnose different disease processes.

questions.question: Does your poop float?
questions.answer: Floating poop can mean you have too much fat in your poop. This can help doctors diagnose different disease processes.

questions.question: Any difficulty pooping?
questions.answer: Nobody enjoys constipation. Constipation can be caused by a variety of things including blockage in your G.I. tract and not enough fiber in your diet. Your doctor will check your abdomen during the physical exam and may order tests to determine the cause.

questions.question: Any changes in the color or consistency of stools?
questions.answer: Poop is something people usually don’t like to discuss, but the color and consistency can be used in diagnosing infections, malnutrition, and other G.I. or inflammatory diseases.

questions.question: Any difficulty getting or maintaining an erection?
questions.answer: As men age, it can be difficult to maintain an erection. There are also other medical conditions that can cause this. Your doctor will be able to address this issue and work with you to help you.

questions.question: Have you noticed any swelling or masses around your testicles?
questions.answer: Masses and swellings can point the doctor to investigate this during the physical exam to determine what the mass is.

questions.question: Any growths or wounds on your penis?
questions.answer: Doctors want to know this because growths may be sign of infection and wounds can be a sign of trauma. Your doctor will want to look at the growths and wounds during the physical exam to diagnose their cause.

questions.question: Any changes to arousal?
questions.answer: Changes in arousal can be related to medication, mental health, and other medical conditions that your doctor will want to address.

questions.question: Any pain or tenderness around breasts?
questions.answer: Pain or tenderness can point to trauma or possible growth in the breast. Your doctor will want to do a breast exam to diagnose the cause.

questions.question: Any changes in shape of breasts or nipples?
questions.answer: Changes in shape of breasts or nipples can be caused by growths or trauma. Your doctor will want to do a breast exam to diagnose the cause.

questions.question: Any hot flashes?
questions.answer: Hot flashes can be part of menopause. Your doctor will ask you multiple questions about your process through menopause, and will be a resource for you as go through menopause.

questions.question: Any lubrication issues/vaginal dryness?
questions.answer: Excess lubrication or excess dryness may be due to a hormonal imbalance that your doctor will want to investigate further with a genital exam and possible blood work.

questions.question: Any difficulty urinating?
questions.answer: Difficulty urinating can be due to various kidney problems including kidney stones, a urinary tract infection, and other medical conditions in the kidney, bladder, and genitals. Your doctor may check your costophrenic angle during the physical exam for kidney stones, and may have you pee in a cup for a UTI.

questions.question: Any discharge around your penis/vagina?
questions.answer: Abnormal amounts of discharge from the penis/vagina can point to an infection that your doctor will want to diagnose and treat.

questions.question: Any cloudiness in urine?
questions.answer: Cloudiness in the urine can point to a kidney, bladder, or genital problem. Your doctor may have you pee in a cup to determine what is clouding up the urine.

questions.question: Any pain while urinating?
questions.answer: Pain while urinating can be due to bladder or genital problems. UTIs and kidney stones commonly cause pain while urinating. Your doctor may want you to pee in a cup and order other tests to determine what in the urine is causing the problem.

questions.question: Do you have to get up in the middle of the night to urinate?
questions.answer: Nobody likes waking up and getting out of the warm, cozy bed to go to the bathroom. Peeing in the middle of the night can be due to many different causes including diabetes, enlarged prostate,and  infections.Your doctor will want to test your urine and possibly your blood to determine the cause.

questions.question: Do you experience an inability to hold urine in?
questions.answer: Inability to hold your urine (incontinence) is something many people across the world have. Your doctor may be able to prescribe medications that could help with this, depending on the cause.

questions.question: Do you have difficulty with starting to urinate or to completely empty?
questions.answer: Difficulty to start urinating or completely emptying can be related to an enlarged prostate, infection, kidney stones, and many other medical conditions. Your doctor will focus on this during the genitourinary part of the physical exam.

questions.question: Any increased bruising?
questions.answer: Bruises can be scary to find. Bruises can be due to low platelet counts, or genetic diseases that makes your blood stick less together. Your doctor will want to run a blood test to find out the causes.

questions.question: Any difficulty stopping bleeding from small cuts?
questions.answer: Cuts that don’t stop bleeding can be due to low platelet counts, or genetic diseases that makes your blood stick together less. Your doctor will want to run a blood test to find out the causes.

containers.title: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any joint pain or swelling?
questions.answer: Long-term pain or swelling in your joints is commonly caused by arthritis, while more recent pain or swelling can be due to other causes. Your doctor will check this out during the physical exam.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any pain with movement?
questions.answer: The area of the pain can point the doctor to which muscles and joints to focus on during the physical exam.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any muscle aches or spasms?
questions.answer: Doctors will want to look at these areas during the physical exam to determine what is causing the spasm or muscle ache.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any low back pain?
questions.answer: Your doctor will ask you more questions about when the pain started and where on the back your pain is. This will prompt your doctor to focus on the lower back during the physical exam,
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any shoulder pain?
questions.answer: Shoulder pain may be caused by an injured nerve, vessel or muscle and depending on where you tell the doctor the pain is (behind the shoulder, in front of the shoulder, etc)  can help your doctor diagnose what is happening.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any pain or difficulty moving your shoulder?
questions.answer: Depending on where the difficulties in movement for your shoulder can help diagnose a deltoid injury, a rotator cuff injury, or bone injury. Move this to the shoulder pain question a few questions above
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any knee pain?
questions.answer: Knee pain is commonly one of the first joints to experience pain from many different medical conditions. Your doctor will want to focus on the knee(s) that are in pain during the physical exam and might run blood tests to determine the underlying medical condition.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any difficulty moving/using hands?
questions.answer: Hands are one of the places rheumatoid arthritis loves to go to. Your doctor, during the physical exam, will focus on the hands and run blood tests and x-rays to determine the underlying medical conditions.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any pain at the hip?
questions.answer: Pain in the hip can be caused by tendonitis, muscle pain, or bone pain. Your doctor will test your range of motion during the physical exam to see which part of the hip the pain is coming from.
questions.container: Muscles, Bones, Joints, Tendons, Ligaments, and Movement

questions.question: Any changes in hair growth/loss?
questions.answer: Hair growth and loss can be due to the natural process of aging or due to hormonal changes.

questions.question: Any new growths on your skin?
questions.answer: Doctors will want to look at any of these growths to make sure they do not pose a risk to your health.

questions.question: Any redness/rashes?
questions.answer: Rashes and redness can be due to allergic reactions, infections, cuts, and bruises, to name a few. Your doctor will want to look at the rash or redness to determine what it is.

questions.question: Any wounds that won’t heal?
questions.answer: Wounds that won’t heal are at higher risk for infection and your doctor will want to address this. There can also be an underlying cause regarding why the wound isn’t healing.

questions.question: Any itching?
questions.answer: Itching is typically caused by allergies, but depending on how bad the itching is, your doctor will focus on the itchy area during the physical exam.

questions.question: Any changes in dryness of skin?
questions.answer: Dryness and cracking of the skin is commonly caused by eczema and psoriasis. Your doctor will look at the skin that is dry to determine what treatment your skin may need.

questions.question: Any lines on fingernails/changes to fingernails?
questions.answer: Our nails change as we age, but they can also change due to nutrition, injury, and other underlying medical conditions.

questions.question: Any feelings of being very cold or very warm?
questions.answer: Being unusually warm or cold can point your doctor to a thyroid problem, a problem with blood vessels (like Raynaud's) or other endocrine related problems. This is something your doctor would order blood tests for to help their diagnosis.

questions.question: Any recent weight loss?
questions.answer: Unexpected weight loss can be due to lots of different things. It can be caused by Celiacs (allergic to gluten), some infections, cancer, and many other diagnoses. This is something your doctor would order blood tests for to help their diagnosis.

questions.question: Did you plan to lose weight?
questions.answer: If you planned on losing weight and were able to, that’s great! Your doctor will be happy to hear that, and it will help your doctor know if the weight loss was expected or unexpected. Unexpected weight loss (aka no change in diet or exercise) can point towards certain medical conditions, which will help in the differential diagnosis.

questions.question: Any increased urge to pee, eat, or increased thirst?
questions.answer: Increased peeing or thirst can be a sign of diabetes, hormonal imbalance, or one of the medications you are on (plus many other areas of the body can play a role). Increased appetite can be related to medications you may be taking or hormonal imbalance.

questions.question: Any recent weight gain?
questions.answer: Weight gain can be caused by many different processes that can be from endocrine, inflammation, G.I, diet and exercise. This is something your doctor would order blood tests for to help their diagnosis.
